title: Jury Finds Rally Organizers Responsible for Charlottesville Violence
content: Jurors found the main organizers of the deadly far-right rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017 liable under state law, awarding more than $25 million in damages, but deadlocked on federal conspiracy charges.

title: CVS, Walgreens and Walmart Fueled Opioid Crisis, Jury Finds
content: This is the first jury verdict in an opioid case. The decision embraced a key legal argument that judges in other opioid cases had recently rejected.

title: Waukesha Death Toll Rises to 6 as Suspect Is Ordered Held on $5 Million Bail
content: The Waukesha County district attorney said “there are not words to describe the risk” posed by the man accused of driving through a Christmas parade in Wisconsin and striking dozens.

more_info.byline: By Mitch Smith, Brandon Dupré, Serge F. Kovaleski and Miriam Jordan

title: ‘Everything Went Black’: The Children Caught in a Christmas Parade Tragedy
content: A child died on Tuesday, and scores of other children were injured when an S.U.V. barreled through the parade on Sunday in Waukesha, Wis.

more_info.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Giulia Heyward

title: The United States and other world powers will tap oil reserves.
content: In an attempt to reduce energy prices, the U.S. will release 50 million barrels of crude. Five other nations also will dip into stockpiles.

title: Biden to Nominate Shalanda Young as Budget Director
content: Ms. Young, the acting head of the Office of Management and Budget, would be the first Black woman to hold the post on a permanent basis.

content: A series of restrictions, including a lockdown in Austria, is expected to put a brake on economic growth.

title: Epstein’s Final Days: Celebrity Reminiscing and a Running Toilet
content: Newly released records show the disgraced financier living a mundane existence in jail before his suicide, while also spinning deceptions until the very end.

title: 8 Spectacular Pies That Taste as Good as They Look

content: The cornmeal that has become a staple of the holiday table reflects millenniums of work by Native Americans — a legacy that Indigenous people are trying to keep alive.

title: How to Make Your Thanksgiving Dinner Less Boring
content: Samin Nosrat will say it: Every year, the meal is a lot of the same. Here are five ways she adds brightness, crunch, freshness and flavor.

title: My Book Was Censored in China. Now It’s Blacklisted — in Texas.
content: Andrew Solomon never expected his books to come under threat in America. But as he writes in this essay, attacks on books are on the rise here, and one of his is under investigation by a state legislature.

content: Unless carefully designed, pandemic office culture risks hurting the least experienced workers in our organizations.

content: The streaming service wants to be more than a place where big names bring passion projects studios have passed on. It’s now trying to make the kind of blockbusters normally seen in theaters.

content: The tennis star won independence while remaining in Beijing’s good graces. But she has been unable to break through China’s resistance to sexual assault allegations.

content: Kick back and laugh about the trials and triumphs of raising tiny humans, with the comedian Michelle Buteau and Jessica Grose of The Times’s parenting newsletter at a virtual event on Dec. 8.

title: NASA Launches New Mission: Crash Into Asteroid, Defend Planet Earth
content: The Double Asteroid Redirection Test spacecraft, launched on Wednesday, could be the first to alter an asteroid’s path, a technique that may be used to defend the planet in the future.

title: Man Is Exonerated in Rape Case Described in Alice Sebold’s Memoir
content: Anthony J. Broadwater was convicted of the 1981 attack in Syracuse, N.Y., in a case the district attorney and a state judge agreed was flawed.

title: Jury Begins Deliberations in Arbery Killing
content: The jurors in Glynn County, Ga., will resume deliberating on Wednesday. The three men accused of killing Ahmaud Arbery face charges of both malice murder and felony murder.

title: Order Blocking New York Times Coverage of Project Veritas Stays in Place
content: A New York trial judge said he needed more time to deliberate on an order that the newspaper argued violates the First Amendment.

title: Man Held in Hawaii for More Than 2 Years Over Mistaken Identity Sues the State
content: Joshua Spriestersbach, who was arrested in 2017 in Honolulu after a police officer mistook him for a man with an outstanding warrant, was held by the state for 32 months, his lawyers said.

content: The Recording Academy, which expanded the top competitions to 10 slots, announces its first ballot since ending its heavily criticized review committees in nearly all categories.
